nodes.bodyText: I would suggest adding Doxygen comments to describe what this does.

What if the class is an interface or abstract class that a value-based class could implement or be derived from, respectively?  For example, java.lang.Comparable.  I think the current implementation of this method will return TR_no in that case.
Right - these are the kinds of case I was worried about.  I was thinking there should be an additional check of isConcreteClass, as is done in J9::CodeGenerator::isMonitorValueType
I would suggest adding a Doxygen comment for this method

Once value types are ultimately supported, is it at all possible for both value types to be enabled and value-based monitor checks to be enabled at the same time?  If so, it might be worthwhile combining these two checks into a single check, to avoid testing the class flags twice.
I think we need Tobi's @tajila feedback on the likelihood of that possibility.

Once value types are ultimately supported, is it at all possible for both value types to be enabled and value-based monitor checks to be enabled at the same time?

I was having the same question and found based on the VM implementation, they look to be mutually exclusive. I'd also be interested in Tobi's @tajila feedback.
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/9fbdc74a6d75d95123a927a6a4bd659542410112/runtime/vm/jnicsup.cpp#L1868-L1873

Yes, the way we have implemented it is mutually exclusive. It has not been explicitly stated that @ValueBased will be deprecated once VTs are supported but I suspect that will be the case. Regardless, we will have the liberty to remove the @ValueBased monitor enter checks at anytime since these are enabled by options.
That being said we made a mask for these checks J9_CLASS_DISALLOWS_LOCKING_FLAGS
The existing monitorenter jithelper can handle all cases.

Tobi @tajila  If we have a build that has J9VM_OPT_VALHALLA_VALUE_TYPES defined and our current code allows java option to set-XX:ValueBasedClassCheck=exception, if a monitor object is value based instance, java.lang.IllegalMonitorStateException will throw instead of java.lang.VirtualMachineError. And the exception message is also for value type instead of value-based. It could be confusing.
Exception in thread "Thread-3" Exception in thread "Thread-2" java.lang.IllegalMonitorStateException: bad object type : object that is synchronized is a value typejava.lang.IllegalMonitorStateException: bad object type : object that is synchronized is a value type

However using -XX:ValueBasedClassCheck=warn will render correct behaviour and message
JVMJ9VM200W bad object type MyCount: object that is synchronized is value-based.

Good point... We can address the dual cases in the helpers. For the time being its safe to assume that we will be dealing with one or the other. If that changes we will change the helpers to detect valueType vs valuebased.
The comments for this method declaration only talk about value types.  They need to be updated to include value-based type checking.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -109,7 +109,7 @@ class OMR_EXTENSIBLE TreeEvaluator: public J9::TreeEvaluator
    *     This method only handles the cases where, at compile time, it's unknown whether the
    *     object is reference type or value type.

nodes.bodyText: Should be a TR_FATAL_ASSERT, especially under debug.

As far as I could recall it's possible that these asserts could be hit on the server side. I don't remember how frequent it was or if things have changed. The same kind of TR_ASSERT check is also used in other four methods of ClassEnv [4]. I'll let @mpirvu help comment on if it should be changed to TR_FATAL_ASSERT based on the latest JITServer development.
[1]
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f10260975a1d840fc8355bb70c4a1d42a9303337/runtime/compiler/env/J9ClassEnv.cpp#L125
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f10260975a1d840fc8355bb70c4a1d42a9303337/runtime/compiler/env/J9ClassEnv.cpp#L783
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f10260975a1d840fc8355bb70c4a1d42a9303337/runtime/compiler/env/J9ClassEnv.cpp#L806
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f10260975a1d840fc8355bb70c4a1d42a9303337/runtime/compiler/env/J9ClassEnv.cpp#L829

@a7ehuo Thank you for not forgetting about JITServer!
The check is there to validate that the flag the server has cached is still consistent with the client's view.
This needs to be done on a case-by-case basis, meaning that there are some flags which are expected to be set once and never change. The check is valid for such flags.
There are other flags that could change back and forth at runtime and we should not put a check for those.
The question here is whether J9ClassIsValueBased can change at runtime, or it is set during class load and immutable afterwards.
Irrespective of the answer, since the checking code is under #ifdef DEBUG TR_ASSERT has the same behavior as TR_ASSERT_FATAL, so it doesn't matter which one we use. I am ok with changing this into a fatal assert.
Once J9ClassIsValueBased or J9ClassIsValueType is set, they're immutable afterwards. I'll change the assert to TR_ASSERT_FATAL

Just so I understand, the reason we can't combine these two into a single check is because the VM helper that will ultimately be called is only expecting one flag value or the other.  That is, it currently can't handle the situation when both flag values are set but it could be adapted to do so.

the reason we can't combine these two into a single check is because the VM helper that will ultimately be called is only expecting one flag value or the other.

This is my understanding too. They're mutually exclusive.

That is, it currently can't handle the situation when both flag values are set but it could be adapted to do so.

The two flags shouldn't be set at the same time. But with the issue mentioned in #11358 (comment). both flags could be set with a build withJAVA_SPEC_VERSION  >= 16 and J9VM_OPT_VALHALLA_VALUE_TYPES is defined. The VM helper will handle it as value type case regardless of which flag is set or what type of monitor object is (value based or value type). It's an issue. It should be prevented (#11358 (comment)).

The two flags shouldn't be set at the same time. But with the issue mentioned in #11358 (comment). both flags could be set with a build withJAVA_SPEC_VERSION >= 16 and J9VM_OPT_VALHALLA_VALUE_TYPES is defined. The VM helper will handle it as value type case regardless of which flag is set or what type of monitor object is (value based or value type). It's an issue. It should be prevented (#11358 (comment)).

Just to clarify. At the moment I don't see us releasing a build where both valuebased checks and J9VM_OPT_VALHALLA_VALUE_TYPES are enabled since the purpose of JEP 390 is to aid migration to valuetypes. If this assumption is incorrect we will modify the helpers to address this. So from the JIT perspective, you do not need to worry about the dual cases. You can just test the mask (J9_CLASS_DISALLOWS_LOCKING_FLAGS) and call the helper. That is what the VM is currently doing. If supporting both modes simultaneously becomes a requirement, then we will have to change the VM to support this. And if you are testing the mask, it will be no effort on your part to support this.
I'll look at how to combine the code in CG to test J9_CLASS_DISALLOWS_LOCKING_FLAGS instead of using two APIs
